Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge's decision met the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act and provided adequate reasons
Application_Facts: Applicant Das provided evidence exceeding 1095 days of physical presence in Canada during a four-year period but lacked detailed documentation
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship approval initially granted, later found unreasonable due to insufficient reasoning
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the citizenship judgeâ€™s decision
Court_Ruling: Decision overturned; case remanded for redetermination
Defendant_Behavior: Citizenship judge failed to specify which residency test was applied or analyze relevant factors
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient reasoning, unclear application of residency test
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard requiring justification, transparency, and intelligibility
Assessment_Factor: Credibility of applicant, sufficiency of documentary evidence, application of correct legal test
Procedural_Issue: Lack of clarity in judicial reasoning and procedural fairness concerns
Application_Basis: Residency duration and quality of supporting documentation
Evidence_Assessed: Residency evidence exceeding 1095 days but lacking detail
Relief_Sought: Overturning of citizenship approval and remand for reassessment
Governing_Rule: Applicant must be physically present in Canada for at least 1095 days within a four-year period
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of detailed documentation supporting residency claim
Outcome: Decision set aside, case remanded for redetermination with opportunity for applicant to submit additional documents
Harm_Assessment: Risk of improper citizenship grant due to inadequate analysis
Cause_Description: Minister challenged approval based on insufficient reasoning and unclear residency test application
Evidence_Handling: Incomplete documentation accepted without thorough scrutiny
Evidence_Issues: Insufficient detail in residency records despite meeting day count
Residency_Compliance: Factual presence met 1095-day threshold; compliance determination hindered by lack of analysis
Evidence_Assessment: Judge accepted credibility but did not assess key residency factors
Decision_Rationale: Unreasonable decision due to lack of clarity on applied test and failure to analyze relevant factors
Evidentiary_Issues: Incomplete documentation, lack of verification of residency details
